status_message:
UPDATE - Feb. 11, 2017: 
Thanks to the keen eye of a member of the public, Antoine Naskathey was spotted on a SkyTrain in Burnaby and arrested a short time later without incident, said police.

ORIGINAL POST: A high-risk offender is on the lam in Vancouver, warned police.
 
Antoine Naskathey, 36, is a on a six-year long-term supervision order for a sexual assault.  Naskathey was convicted for breaking into homes and sexually assaulting female residents in 2001 and 2009, and has more than 50 convictions since 1994, mainly for property crimes and theft.

Naskathey is gender variant and identifies as a female at times, said police, who described the fugitive as aboriginal, 5'10" tall, 161 pounds, with long brown hair and brown eyes.

Naskathey had a temporary residence at a Vancouver halfway house, and was being transferred to a residence in Saskatchewan. On Feb. 8, Naskathey was supposed to be on a flight from Vancouver to Regina, but missed the it, and is now unaccounted for.

A Canada-wide warrant has been issued for Antoine's arrest.

Anyone who sees or knows the whereabouts of Antoine Naskathey is asked to call 911 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.

UPDATE - Feb. 9, 2017 - Authorities say Richard Ian Ellis has now moved to Chilliwack to reside. 

ORIGINAL POST - Feb .4, 2017 - A public warning has been issued about Richard Ian Ellis, 68, is a high-risk sex offender who plans to live in Hope. 

He has a long criminal history which includes sex assault, possession of child pornography and printing/publishing child pornography. 

"He has maintained a predatory and opportunistic pattern of sexually offending against children and poses a significant risk to the safety of prepubescent girls," said BC Corrections. 

Ellis must follow 18 court-ordered conditions including having no contact with girls 16 years old or under, unless necessary for a store transaction, and not possessing any devices that can record images. 

He is 5' 10" tall, 200 pounds, with very thin brown hair and hazel eyes.

A public warning has been issued again for Jeffrey Goddard, 27, who is living in Surrey. 

The high-risk sex offender has a criminal history, which includes sexual assault, invitation to sexual touching under 16, communicate via computer to lure a child under 16, and personating a peace officer.

"Goddard has maintained a pattern of sexual offending against male youth and adults and communicating via computer to lure male and female youth, in both an opportunistic and predatory manner," said BC Corrections in a news release on Wednesday.

He must follow 21 conditions including a curfew, not communicating with anyone under 18, and not using any social networking sites.

status_message:
Vancouver police Department are warning the public about a high-risk sexual offender who is now living in the city. 
 
Michael Wayne Carpenter, 46, is serving a 10-year long-term supervision order, with convictions for three counts each of sex assault with a weapon, forcible confinement, and uttering threats to cause death or bodily harm.
 
Carpenter poses a risk to the safety of vulnerable female children, teens, and adults, said police. He will be living at a correctional halfway house in Vancouver.
 
He is white, 5'9" tall, weighs 180 pounds, and has brown short hair and blue eyes.
 
Carpenter must follow certain conditions, which includes:
 
-not to consume, purchase, or possess alcohol or drugs
-not to own, use or possess a computer, or any technological device that would allow access to the Internet
-not to be in the presence of any female children under the age of 18, except in certain conditions
-not to purchase, acquire, possess or access pornography or sexually explicit material
-report all friendships, sexual relationships, and intimate relationships with women
-not to go to Kamloops
-not to enter any private dwelling or places including, but not limited to hotels, motels, rooming houses, SRO residences, private residence/dwelling, or vehicles
 
Anyone witnessing Carpenter violating any of these conditions is asked to call 911.

status_message:
Five earthquakes ‚Äî with the largest at 5.7 magnitude ‚Äî were recorded on Friday about 150 kilometres west of Port Hardy, on the northern tip of Vancouver Island. 

No tsunami alert was issued and no damage has been recorded in the sparsely populated area. 

The quakes were the Cascadia subduction zone where two plates of the Earth's crust meet and seismic activity is common. 

The squeezing of the plates causes about 300 small tremors every year in southwestern B.C., but Natural Resources warns the plates could eventually snap loose, causing a devastating offshore earthquake with a magnitude of 9 or greater.

The last time such a quake happened was in 1700.

status_message:
A Vancouver-based campaign wants to introduce you to Invisible Dog. 

Last year, 4,358 dogs were euthanized by Canadian shelters. Many of them could have been saved by being adopted. 

Home at Last Dog Rescue wants people to adopt dogs from shelters, rather than buy them.

"When people purchase their pets, that's one less home for a rescue animal, and I think that's not something everyone considers," said Maureen Pickell of the group.

"If this campaign saves just one rescue dog's life, it'll be worth it."

http://bit.ly/1YcLOCh

Some of Vancouver's gray utility boxes are getting a makeover to help stop graffiti artists in their tracks.

The city is asking artists to submit designs to wrap around 27 of the boxes to discourage vandalism. Any artist who has their design chosen will be paid $1,000.

In 2011, students from Emily Carr University of Art and Design helped redecorate boxes along Granville Street (pictured below,) to great success.

A new bridge to replace the Massey Tunnel that connects Richmond and Delta will be tolled. The province announced other new details as well:

‚Ä¢ 10 lanes
‚Ä¢ Three kilometres long
‚Ä¢ Four general lanes, one transit/HOV lane in each direction
‚Ä¢ One cycling and pedestrian path on one side of the bridge
‚Ä¢ Upgrades to three highway interchanges
‚Ä¢ Estimated $3.5 billion cost.

Construction is slated to start in 2017 and finish in about five years.

"This will be the largest bridge ever built in B.C. When completed, it will address what is now the worst traffic bottleneck in the province," said Transportation and Infrastructure Minister Todd Stone.

http://trib.al/Ws6eFGi
link_name: Animation Of Bridge Planned To Replace Massey Tunnel

status_message:
Vancouver police are looking for the attacker who sucker-punched a man in the face, sending him to hospital with serious injuries.

The victim, 49, was smoking outside Pub 340 on Cambie Street just after 10 p.m. on Aug. 31. A stranger punched him in the face and knocked him unconscious, police said in a media release. (Watch the surveillance video at the 35-second mark.)

As the victim lay bloodied on the ground, the attacker calmly walked away, added police. The punch was seemingly unprovoked, said investigators.

The suspect is described as Aboriginal, in his 30s, 5'10", with a medium build, light complexion and several tattoos. At the time, he was wearing a black jacket with the word "Headrush" on the back.

Anyone with information about this incident or the attacker is asked to call Vancouver police at (604) 717-2541 or Crime Stoppers at 1 (800) 222-8477.

Walter, the blind sea otter who was living at the Vancouver Aquarium, has died.
Nicknamed "Wally," the animal was rescued near Tofino after being shot in 2013. He wasn't fit for release back into the wild because of his age and injuries, so he found a new home at the aquarium.

He even made a new friend, Tanu, shortly after arriving. The pair are pictured holding hands. 

Wally died early Wednesday morning after being ill for most of this year.

status_message:
Broadcaster Rafe Mair was a minister in Bill Bennett's Socred cabinet. On the hearing of the former B.C. premier's passing, Mair wrote: 

"I wanted to send a short note to tell you just how sad I am at the death of Bill Bennett. Even though we knew it was coming it's still a hell of a shock.

I think the measure of the man is shown up by the fact that all of his cabinet ministers would have crawled a mile over broken glass for him. For me, he gave me superb jobs to do and my memories are of gratitude for his kindnesses and for having met the man I think history will record was one of the best premiers British Columbia has ever had.

He was not only my boss but my friend.

My heart goes out to Audrey and all the family."

http://huff.to/1XHusiD

(Photo: CP)

Leon is Aboriginal, 5'11", 195 pounds with brown eyes and black hair. He wears perscription glasses and has a tattoo of "Leon" on his right hand, as well as wings and a cross on his upper back.

Police said he was last seen wearing a grey "Puma" hoode and carrying a black backpack.

Anyone who sees Leon is asked to stay away and call 911.

"Compelling circumstances" have led Vancouver police to warn the public about a high-risk sex offender living in the city.
 
Christopher Michael Watts, 55, is a three-time federal offender who has completed his sentence for manslaughter, sexual touching and sexual assault. He has shown a pattern of providing drugs to girls and having sex with them "without regard for their ability to consent," said police in a news release.
 
Watts is described as white, six feet tall, 160 pounds, with brown hair and brown eyes. He is under a long-term supervision order with the following conditions:
 
-not to consume, purchase or possess alcohol or illegal drugs
-not to own, use or possess a computer or any device that would allow access to the internet
-not to be in the presence of any girls under 18 unless accompanied by a responsible adult who knows his criminal history and has been approved by his parole supervisor
-report all friendships, sexual relationships and intimate relationships with women.

Anyone see Watts violating any of these conditions is asked to call 911.

status_message:
"Our city has a long and proud history of welcoming refugees and helping them start new lives with hope, security, and freedom here in Canada.
 
Vancouver and communities across the country have a longstanding commitment to welcoming refugees and their families in times of need. This is at the heart of our inclusive, compassionate, and diverse city.
 
Vancouver has taken steps to increase our capacity to welcome refugees, and we will continue to do so ‚Äì the City has contributed $4.1 million in land and grants for the construction of an innovative new Vancouver Welcome House for refugees.
 
In responding to the current crisis, we are building on the momentum of the Syrian refugee forum we held in September at City Hall, which brought together key settlement experts and hundreds of members of the public who wanted to learn more about how our community can do its part to help.
 
Today, Deputy Mayor Reimer represented the City in joining a Call for Action to help support the Syrian Refugee resettlement to BC. We have started working with Immigrant Services Society of BC and other key supporters, including the Mayors of other cities such as Coquitlam and Surrey.
 
In the coming months, local governments and agencies are collectively committed to assisting Syrian refugees settling in the Lower Mainland.  
 
These new arrivals will come with little more than their families and hope. They need help finding housing and jobs, learning English and navigating a new culture and city.
 
I encourage you find out how you can help welcome our new arrivals by visiting the Immigrant Settlement Services (ISS) of BC website at: ISSBC.org.
 
Working together with ISS of BC, the City is helping coordinate a response to support refugees in Vancouver by providing information for people with offers of donations, looking to volunteer or get more information. You can also find out how to help by visiting vancouver.ca or through the VanConnect App.
 
When I recently spoke with Prime Minister Trudeau, one of the first things I expressed was the willingness of Vancouver to help with the successful integration of refugees in our communities.
 
We know that civic facilities, including libraries and communities centres will be important venues for our newcomers' sense of belonging. These places allow Syrian and other refugees a place to learn language and connect with others.
 
I am proud that the City will continue to work with federal and provincial partners as well as local community groups to help give our new arrivals a true Vancouver welcome."
 
- Mayor Gregor Robertson

(Photo: Freedom House/Flickr)

Abbotsford police are looking for a suspect who stole an 83-year-old veteran's scooter. 

The scooter was taken from outside the Abbotsford Legion sometime Friday morning, police said in a news release.

The victim said he talked with a man who seemed very interested in the scooter before it went missing, said Const. Paul Walker. 

Police released video of the suspect who identified himself as "Kevin." He's described as a white man in his 40s who is 5'8" with an average build and short, brown hair.

The scooter is red with a roof, windshield, and black basket attached to the front. Police ask that anyone who has seen the scooter or who can identify Kevin call the department at 604-859-5225 or anonymously through Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.
link_name: Person Of Interest In Abbotsford, B.C. Scooter Theft

Transit Police in Vancouver are looking for a man suspected of groping a woman on the SkyTrain.

The woman got on the train at Broadway/Commercial station on the night of Aug. 12 and sat down. It's alleged a man seating behind her reached out and touched her breast. She immediately stood up and confronted him, said a Transit Police news release on Friday.

When the train arrived at Stadium Station, the woman grabbed the man's hand and pulled him onto the platform, but he managed to get free.

The suspect is described as Indo-Canadian, in his 20s, 5'8" tall, with a thin build, and medium-length curly black hair. 

"We commend the victim of this assault for the actions she took. Sexual offences on the transit system are a priority for the Transit Police. We are committed to taking all incidents of sexual assault and sexual harassment very seriously and investigating thoroughly," said spokeswoman Anne Drennan.

Statement from Premier Christy Clark:

"On behalf of the Government of British Columbia, I want to congratulate Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his newly appointed cabinet ministers.

I am pleased to see British Columbia will be well represented at the cabinet table. I know ministers Jody Wilson-Raybauld, Harjit Sajjan and Carla Qualtrough will be strong, passionate advocates not just for our province, but for our shared priorities, like renewing the Softwood Lumber Agreement, LNG development, increasing support for international trade, investing in infrastructure and immigration, as well as fully including First Nations in our diverse economy.

Working on these priorities will ensure British Columbia continues to create jobs and grow its substantial contribution to confederation.

I am looking forward to working with Prime Minister Trudeau and his cabinet as we continue to build a stronger, more-prosperous Canada and British Columbia."

A Canadian has set the world record for ... the most motorcycles driven over a human laying on a bed of nails in under two minutes. The previous world record was held by an Italian.

Seventy motorcycles drove over Burnaby Q. Orbax at Fright Nights at PNE/Playland in Vancouver on Monday. 

Orbax is part of The Monsters of Schlock, who have also set Guinness World Records for most mousetraps released on a human tongue in one minute, longest truck pull with meat hooks in a person's back, and weightlifting using hooks in a human face. 

(Photo: Darryl Dyck/Canadian Press)

Abbotsford police are warning the public about a sex offender who has completed his sentence.

Gary Reid Hoare, 65, was convicted of sexual assault, invitation to sexual touching and making child pornography, Const. Ian MacDonald said in a media release.

Hoare is 5'10", 200 pounds, with grey hair and blue eyes. He must follow several court-ordered conditions, including staying away from parks, schools, daycares, or pools. He's also not allowed to contact girls under 16, and can't leave B.C., said police.

Anyone who sees Hoare breaking his conditions is asked to call police.

A man wanted in an apparent indecent act last year at an amusement centre in Abbotsford is suspected in a second incident in May, said police.

Lab results from samples taken there as well as from a November incident at Castle Fun Park match the same suspect, said police.

In the earlier case, a 24-year-old woman playing pinball with some friends was approached from behind by a man who appeared to be touching his genitals and recording something with a cellphone. 

Police are looking for the suspect whose photo from surveillance cameras was released, and are concerned there may be other similar incidents.

Coquitlam RCMP have issued a Canada-wide warrant for a man missing from a psychiatric hospital.

Jason Kirkpatrick, 35, left the Cypress Lodge at Riverview grounds on Thursday and is unlawfully at large, according to a news release. 

He is white, 5'7", and 155 pounds with short brown hair and a bald spot.

RCMP say Kirkpatrick is suffering from a mental illness. The public is advised to stay away and call 911 if they spot him. 

Anyone with more information should call Coquitlam RCMP at 604-945-1550 and quote file number 2015-35127.

The Pattullo Bridge will be closed to all vehicle traffic from 9 p.m. on Friday (Oct. 16) until noon on Sunday (Oct. 18). Emergency vehicles will still have access to cross the bridge, and the sidewalk will stay open for cyclists and pedestrians.

Abbotsford police are looking for a man who allegedly committed an indecent act at Castle Fun Park last year.

The suspect approached a 24-year-old woman from behind while she was playing pinball on Nov. 8, 2014, Const. Ian MacDonald said in a news release Friday.

The suspect appeared to be touching his genitals while recording something on a cellphone, he said. He only walked away when the victim noticed what was happening.

The suspect, believed to be in his mid-30s, is described as a white, 5'10", 180 pounds with a chubby face, and a "5 o'clock shadow."

He was wearing a blue ball cap, a light blue Canucks hoodie, and jeans.

If you recognize the suspect, call Abbotsford police at 604 859-5225, or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.

ORIGINAL POST: Surrey RCMP are looking for a suspect in an alleged sex assault on Sunday afternoon. 

A man sexually and physically assaulted a woman in a wooded area near the intersection of Fraser Highway and 140th Street, said a police news release. The suspect was last seen leaving on foot; the victim was treated for injuries.

The suspect is described as black, over six feet tall, about 160 pounds, in his late 30's, with short black hair. He has a distinctive "wandering" or "lazy" right eye, said police.

Vancouver police have issued a Canada-wide warrant for a high-risk sex offender who didn't return to his halfway house on Thursday.

Keith Edward Caouette, 45, is a two-time offender who served 14 years for kidnapping and sexual assault with a weapon. He left his halfway house around 5:30 p.m. and didn't come back by curfew, police said in a media release.

Caouette is described as aborginal, six feet tall, 300 pounds, with green eyes and brown hair tied in a ponytail. He has a full sleeve on his left arm, three skulls on his right bicep, and a skull band on his right wrist.

Police said Caouette is a high risk to reoffend violently. Anyone who sees him is asked to stay away from him, and to call 911.

Coquitlam RCMP are looking for a man accused of trying to lure an 11-year-old girl into his car.

On Sept. 11, the girl was riding her bike to school near the Westwood Park area around 8 a.m., according to a media release.

The unidentified man pulled up beside her in a car and asked if she needed a ride. The girl refused and carried on to school.  

The student described the suspect as a clean-shaven, white man in his 20s or 30s with blond hair and blue eyes. He was wearing a black shirt and blue, square-framed glasses.

RCMP say he was driving a small car that was either blue or black.

Anyone with information can contact the Coquitlam RCMP at 604-945-1550 and quote file number 2015-31003, or call Crimestoppers to remain anonymous.

A magnitude 5.5 earthquake was detected off the coast of Vancouver Island Thursday, marking the area's second minor quake in two days.

This morning's tremor struck 198 kilometres west of Port Hardy around 6 a.m., and likely wasn't felt on the surface. 

On Tuesday, a 4.2 magnitude quake hit just before 5:30 a.m., 201 kilometres from the same municipality.

Did you feel anything?
A magnitude 4.4 earthquake was recorded at 6:30 a.m. Tuesday off Vancouver Island, 200 kilometres west of Port Hardy.

Police have issued a warning about a high-risk sex offender who is living in Vancouver, out of concern for public safety.

Michael Wayne Carpenter, 44, is a federal offender who has been released from custody after serving an eight-year sentence for sexual assault with a weapon, forcible confinement, and threatening to cause death or bodily harm. Carpenter's multiple sex assault convictions included attacks on hotel employees. 

"It is believed he poses a risk of significant harm to the safety of female children, youth and adults," said police in a Friday news release.
 
He is described as white, 5'9" tall, 180 lbs. with brown shaved hair and blue eyes.
 
Subject to a long-term supervision order, Carpenter is must follow conditions including:
 -not to consume, purchase, or possess alcohol or drugs
-not to own, use or possess a computer, or any device with Internet access
-not to be in the presence of any girls under the age of 18
-report all friendships, sexual relationships and intimate relationships with women.

UPDATE - Aug. 22: Darren Wheatley was located by police in Vancouver and arrested without incident. 

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver police are looking for a high-risk sex offender who has again failed to return to his halfway house.
 
Darren Wheatley, 45, is wanted for breaching his release conditions on Thursday night. 
 
Wheatley spent 10 years in prison for sexual assault, overcoming resistance by choking, and sexual assault causing bodily harm after three separate attacks on women in Ontario.

In March, he also failed to return to his Vancouver halfway house and was arrested in Kelowna two weeks later.
 
Wheatley is aboriginal, six feet tall, 230 pounds, and has a large build. He has brown eyes and short black hair, with has tattoos of a cow, a skull and a feather on his right arm and a script-like design on his left arm.
 
Anyone who sees him is asked to not approach him and call 911.

(Photo: Vancouver Police Department)

Police conducted a "high-risk" stop (with their guns drawn) of a motorcyclist in Victoria around 4 a.m. on Aug. 9 ‚Äî because the man had what appeared to be an assault rifle sticking out of his backpack. 

After handcuffing the man, police discovered it was a very realistic replica, they said in a news release.

He told officers the transported the replica weapon in his backpack so that he wouldn't scare anyone. 

He also failed two roadside breathalyzer tests. The man received a 90-day immediate driving ban, and his replica assault rifle was seized. No charges are pending.

HEALTH ADVISORY: Restaurants have been asked to boil all oysters harvested from B.C. as more illnesses are reported.

Vancouver Coastal Health said a naturally occuring bacteria found in the province's coastal waters can cause a stomach illness, and 31 cases connected to raw oysters have been reported this year.

Symptoms include cramps, vomiting, diarrhea, and fever that can last up to a week.

The public is advised to cook oysters at home as well, and only to eat raw oysters if they've been harvested out of the province.

(Photo: Getty)

Recall Warning - Heinz Apple broccoli, pea & brown rice and Mott's Fruitsations Fruit Rockets (unsweetened strawberry) have been recalled due to potential for spoilage.

They should be thrown out or returned to the store where you bought them, said the Canadian Food Inspection Agency. 

If an infant or child has been fed the products, discontinue use and monitor for symptoms. Consumption of spoiled food may cause symptoms such as upset stomach, vomiting and diarrhea. If you have any concerns, please seek medical attention, said the agency.

Surrey police say they've shut down a suspected drug house in the 12900 block of 108th Avenue.
 
Officers started an investigation because they believed people inside were supplying street-level drugs to visitors. 

RCMP said a search of the house resulted in 10 arrests, and the seizure of:
‚Ä¢Over 50 grams of crack cocaine (500 doses) 
‚Ä¢40 grams of heroin (400 doses) 
‚Ä¢A loaded handgun
‚Ä¢A small amount of cannabis, hashish, and methadone. 
‚Ä¢$1,700 cash
‚Ä¢Materials used in packaging, distributing drugs.

Weapons charges and possession for the purpose of trafficking and weapon will be recommended against a 57-year-old man and a 41-year-old woman, who are both known to police. 

(Surrey RCMP photo)

Major crimes investigators on Vancouver Island are joining the search for 18-year-old Delores Brown who went missing on July 27.

Brown, who also goes by Deedee, lives on Penelakut Island and was seen leaving for her grandmother's house in Chemainus. 

Brown, who left her phone behind, has never gone missing before. The disappearance is very out of character, said Ladysmith RCMP.

Relatives and the community have been knocking on doors and searching the shorelines for her. 

Brown is described as First Nations, about 5'6" tall, and 120 pounds. She was wearing blue sweatpants and a black and white T-shirt.

UPDATE - 10:40 p.m.: Abbotsford police have found the couple.

ORIGINAL POST: Abbotsford police are looking for a couple in their 80s who haven't been seen since Thursday afternoon.

Robert and Martha Mackay walked away from their home near Clearbrook Road and South Fraser Way around 1 p.m. and were reported missing two hours later. 

They may be confused, said police.

An abandoned property in East Vancouver assessed at $813,000 has turned into a smelly dumping ground. After neighbours' complaints, city crews have started to clean up public property, but the owner is still responsible for clearing the yard.

Abbotsford police have arrested a 21-year-old man in a string of random pellet gun attacks that have injured nine pedestrians. 

Investigators are looking for at least one other person involved in the assaults and mischief. They released images that show a driver and a second person with a pellet gun in the suspect car. 

Since mid-July, there have been 24 pellet gun attacks at various locations in Abbotsford, hitting people, vehicles, and homes.

RCMP believe there may be other victims or witnesses in the case of a Port Coquitlam man charged with sexually assaulting and luring underage victims.

Colin Clarence Graham, 44, is also charged with uttering a threat. Police released his photo to urge others to come forward.

Graham is described as 5'11" and 179 pounds with blue eyes and a shaved head.

He's been released under conditions including:
‚Ä¢ Not to contact the victims
‚Ä¢ Not to access the Internet
‚Ä¢ Not to communicate with anyone under 16 years old.
‚Ä¢ Not to possess any alcohol, drugs, weapons.
‚Ä¢ Required to stay at a recovery house.

RCMP have issued a Canada-wide warrant for a high-risk sex offender who failed to return to his Vancouver halfway house in May.

Gerald Richard McLean, 46, sexually assaulted a child in 2000 and a teen in 1995. He's under a long-term supervision order after finishing a two-year sentence for sex assault. 

Police say they've received information that McLean may have recently been near Quesnel. He is considered to be an experienced outdoorsman and prefers to be in rural areas.

McLean is white, 5'7" tall, 175 pounds, with green eyes, a goatee, and long blond hair possibly worn in a ponytail, said RCMP.

He has a tattoo of an eagle on his left upper arm, a skull on his shoulder, a tribal band on his right upper arm, and the word "prospector" on his back. He was last seen wearing a black baseball cap, black hoodie with an emblem on the back, brown pants, and black boots.

McLean is believed to be armed. Anyone who sees him, or knows where he is, should not approach and call 911 right away.

(Photo: B.C. RCMP)

UPDATE - July 23, 4 p.m.: RCMP spotted Ronald Teneycke on Thursday morning in a stolen vehicle. After a pursuit that involved the emergency response team and the RCMP helicopter, he was arrested.

"We are thankful the arrest was made without any injuries to our officers, the general public, or Teneycke," said police.

ORIGINAL POST: A manhunt is underway in Oliver, B.C. for Ronald Teneycke, a prolific offender who allegedly robbed a store before assaulting a driver and stealing his vehicle.

Teneycke's truck was found in a rural area on a forest service road east of the town. Police are currently doing a full-scale search of the area.

Oliver RCMP said that Teneycke posed as a hitchhiker and when a man driving a 1999 White GMC picked him up, Teneycke allegedly assaulted him with a weapon and stole the truck.

The truck has B.C. licence plate 7621 GG, with "Okanagan Rustic Furniture" written across the back window.

Teneycke was in the news in 2007 after serving an eight-year prison sentence for sexually assaulting a teenage girl.

Police believe Teneycke is extremely dangerous and may be armed. They're also asking that people did not disclose details of the manhunt on social media for everyone's safety. 

(RCMP photo)

Ikea is urging Canadian customers to check that their dressers are securely anchored to the wall. 

In the U.S., the company is "recalling" about 27 million dressers and chests after two American children died in separate incidents when Malm chests fell on them last year, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

 Ikea is offering customers free wall anchoring kits. 

"IKEA furniture is safe when assembled and installed according to assembly instructions," said the company. "All IKEA chests of drawers contain tip-over restraints with assembly instructions in the flat package upon purchase."

Any customer who did not keep the anti-tip devices can pick one up at any IKEA location, or calling 1-866-866-IKEA in Canada: http://huff.to/1OyB1f7

TransLink buses will look dirtier for the next while, but for good reason.

The company says it won't be washing bus exteriors during the current water shortage.

Buses are usually washed at transit centres at the end of each service day. TransLink uses reclaimed water for most of the wash cycle, except the final rinse which uses fresh water.

At the largest facility in Vancouver with more than 500 buses, that translates to 30,000 litres of water conserved each day.

Last week, TransLink started washing buses every second day. But now, exterior washes will be done only in "exceptional circumstances," said the company. Interior cleans will continue.

(Canadian Press photo)

Reminder for your morning commute! New penalties are in place for drivers who hog the left lane in B.C. 

Here's what you need to know:

‚Ä¢ You may still use the left lane to pass, allow traffic to merge or prepare for a turn. 
‚Ä¢ The new rules apply to highways where the speed limit is more than 80 km/h.
‚Ä¢ When roads are congested and speeds drop to 50 km/h or less, you may move to the left lane to help traffic flow.
‚Ä¢ Lawbreakers could be hit with a $167 fine and three penalty points.

Statement from TransLink on what went wrong today:

"We thank our customers for their patience and apologize for the major inconvenience they experienced this afternoon because of the SkyTrain delay. The delay occurred at the peak of rush hour service, which affected our most regular daily customers. While we recognize the inconvenience and longer commute times, we appreciate their patience and calm behaviour while our staff worked to repair the problem and help redirect customers via alternate means.
 
While the specific cause of the delay is still under investigation, a technical issue at 4:10 p.m. caused 19 trains between Royal Oak and Waterfront stations to stop running. Expo Line trains continued to run between Edmonds and King George stations, and Millennium Line trains continued to run between Columbia and VCC-Clark stations.
 
Many trains were stopped between stations; several were attended by a SkyTrain Attendant within 5-10 minutes and driven manually to the nearest station. Staff attended the majority of the remainder of the trains within 30 minutes.
 
Customers broke out of three different trains in the Nanaimo SkyTrain area, so we had to turn off power in the area to ensure customers were safe and clear of trains. Attending to these customers delayed SkyTrain system recovery by an additional hour.
 
25 buses provided shuttle service between affected stations. We deployed over 100 staff to help customers, respond to questions and assist with crowds ‚Äì including 60 SkyTrain Attendants on trains and at stations; 16 Transit Police officers and five Transit Security units; 13 support staff; and eight transit supervisors.
 
7 additional technicians worked to bring the system back on as quickly as possible.
 
By 6:10 p.m., we were able to provide some service with SkyTrain Attendants manually driving trains in the affected area. We restored full service by 6:45 p.m."

(Instagram photo courtesy of Tara Villett)

Vancouver police are asking for the public's help to solve the mystery surrounding a man's serious head injury.  
 
Around 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, May 30, a 58-year-old man watched the hockey game at home and went for a walk in the Kits Beach area. He returned home around 10:30 p.m. and appeared dazed and confused, suffering from what appeared to be a minor head injury. 

When his partner asked about the wounds, he recalled being in a confrontation with somebody at the beach, but couldn't provide any details about what happened.

He rested at home that night, but was found unresponsive the next day. He was rushed to hospital where he underwent two surgeries to repair a life-threatening brain bleed. He remains in hospital in critical condition.
 
Police continue to investigate the cause of his injuries and have done an extensive canvas of video and witnesses in the neighbourhood.
 
"We are looking for the public's help to put the pieces of this puzzle together," said Const. Brian Montague.
 
The man is white, 5'10" tall, with a heavy build, short salt-and-pepper hair, and a dark complexion. At the time, he was wearing a New York Yankees baseball hat, an orange T-shirt, cargo shorts, flip-flops and was carrying a black backpack.

A baby owl who fell from his nest during the Little Bobtail Lake wildfire has a new home. 

Fire crews found him on Tuesday. He was too young to fly and vulnerable to prey, so he was taken to a wildlife recovery centre in Quesnel, and then to the O.W.L. Orphaned Wildlife Rehabilitation Society in Delta.

The baby will be raised with an adult male and female owl. Once he can survive on his own, he'll be returned to his natural habitat.

Crews named him Norman, after Norman Lake.

(Photo from BC Forest Fire Info)

Two pygmy goats named Thistle and Bramble are the newest additions to the Vancouver Island Regional Correctional Centre.

UPDATE - June 9, 2015: Homicide investigators said Darwin Lescano was arrested by Vancouver police and is now charged with second-degree murder in the death of his mother.

ORIGINAL POST: Police are looking for a Richmond, B.C. man wanted in connection with the death of his mother.

On Tuesday, RCMP found the body of Redelma Belisario, 62, in a home in the 11000 block of Woodhead Road in Richmond. Homicide investigators believe she was killed, according to a news release.

Her son, Darwin Lescano, 38, is a suspect in her death. He is 5'6", 141 pounds with black hair, brown eyes, a slim build, and shaved or cropped hair.

Police said he could be a risk to the public. If you see him, do not approach him and call 911.
Summer looks good on you, Vancouver.

Abbotsford police are warning about 17 street robberies since January. Anywhere from two to eight suspects armed with weapons like knives and cutting shears have confronted people in public places across the city (see map) and taken their cellphones, cash, and jewelry.

Victims have suffered minor injuries to ones requiring hospitalization.

Police said the suspects and victims are usually on foot, and the robberies tend to happen in less populated and less well-lit areas. They remind people to walk in pairs or groups and to stay near busier locations with good lighting.

UPDATE: Gary Vogrig was captured on Wednesday night, while drinking near Second Beach in Stanley Park, said police.

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver police are looking for a high-risk sex offender who failed to return to his halfway house on Monday night. 

Gary Vogrig, 51, has an extensive criminal history that includes charges of uttering threats, assault, sex assault, unlawful confinement, and robbery, said police. He is currently on statutory release serving a sentence of 4.5 yeras for sexual assault and threatening. 

Vogrig is white, 5'11" tall, 165 lbs., with shaved brown hair, a moustache, and hazel eyes. He has a tattoo of a small cross on his right arm, an unfinished wolverine on his left arm and four burn marks on his left forearm. 

If you see Vogrig, call 911 and do not approach him, said police.

Police are looking for an "armed and dangerous" suspect involved in a high-speed car chase through Metro Vancouver.

The suspect allegedly tried to shoot a police officer Monday morning in New Westminster, but his gun didn't work, according to a news release. The man then drove away through New Westminster and Burnaby. 

Police say the suspect is a white man with dark hair and tattoos on his arms and neck. The car is described as a white, four-door Buick Lacrosse, similar to the one in this photo. 

The vehicle has Alberta licence plate J33 225. 

Officials are asking anyone who sees the car to keep their distance and call 911.

UPDATE - July 7, 2015: Vancouver police arrested Timothy Daniel Jones at a rooming house in the Downtown Eastside, and he remains in custody.

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver police are looking for a high-risk sex offender after he failed to return to his halfway house.

Timothy Daniel Jones, 48, has been convicted three times for sexual assaults against teenage and adult women. Police say he is considered a high-risk to re-offend.

He's on statutory release, after receiving a sentence of one year and eight months for breaching long-term supervision order.

Jones is white, 6' tall, with brown eyes, brown hair, and a tattoo of Pegasus on his upper right arm. 

Anyone who sees Jones should not approach him and call 911 immediately.

UPDATE: Police arrested Richard Thomas Galt on Thursday morning in Abbotsford.

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver police are looking for a high-risk sex offender who failed to return to his halfway house Monday night.
 
Richard Thomas Galt, 46, has a history of sexually assaulting women and children and is considered a high risk to re-offend, said police.

He is currently on statutory release after a sentence of almost four years for uttering threats, break and enter, and failing to comply with his probation order.
 
Galt is described as aboriginal, 5'8" tall, 240 lbs., with long black hair and several tattoos, including a wizard on his left forearm, tribal design on the right forearm, and a heart and dagger on his left upper arm. He walks with a cane, and was last seen wearing a light blue T-shirt and blue jeans.
 
Anyone who sees him, or knows where is is, should not approach him, and should call 911 right away, said police.

UPDATE: Vancouver police said officers arrested Gordon Alex David on Tuesday "without incident," while he was walking on Granville Street.

ORIGINAL POST: Gordon Alexander David, 34, is wanted in the killing of his spouse Cady Quaw, 23. She was found in a Surrey home on Sunday and later died of her injuries, said police.

A second woman who was found in the home remains in hospital in stable condition.

David is wanted for manslaughter and aggravated assault.

The Integrated Homicide Investigation Team says David is armed and dangerous. Anyone who knows where he is should not approach him and immediately call 911.

UPDATE: RCMP arrested Myles on Tuesday at a home near Duncan, B.C. Police allege that he committed "additional violent offences" at that home.

ORIGINAL POST: North Cowichan/Duncan RCMP is looking for a dangerous offender who has a violent history, including an attack on an 18-year-old woman. 

Nathan Myles, 35, who has been living in the Cowichan Valley, is wanted on charges of harassment, unlawful confinement, and assault with a weapon, said police.

Myles is described as 6"1', 166 pounds, with brown hair and blue eyes, and is believed to have recently cut his hair short.

Police consider him dangerous, and "caution the public on approaching him."

Coquitlam RCMP are looking for two men who forced a woman into their silver SUV and sexually assaulted her on April 16 around 2:30 a.m. 

The woman was walking home in the area of Foster Avenue and Linton Street when a vehicle stopped to ask her for directions. At that point, she was pulled into the vehicle and attacked, said police in a news release. 

She was dropped off around Austin Avenue and Draycott Street and she walked home. She reported the assault to RCMP the next morning. 

Police have released this composite sketch of the driver.

Both suspects are described as dark skinned, in their mid to late 20s, with short dark hair and dark eyes. The passenger was about 5'7" tall. 

The vehicle was possibly a 1998-2003 Dodge Durango, said police.

UPDATE: Police captured Shawn Merrick on Wednesday night (May 13) in Langley. A police helicopter found him hiding on the roof of a house, and other units moved in to arrest him.

ORIGINAL POST: A convicted killer has walked away from the minimum-security Mission Institution. Shawn Merrick, 43, was discovered missing on Tuesday, said justice officials.

Merrick is currently serving an indeterminate sentence for the 2006 second-degree murder of Shelley Lynn Devoe in Coquitlam. He also had a history of robberies in the Lower Mainland.

He is 5'8", 141 pounds, with blue eyes and brown hair. He has a burn scar all over his right forearm and a two-inch scar on his neck. He also has a tattoo of skulls on his left upper arm, a heart with the name "Jade" on his right upper back, a dragon on his right upper arm and on the left side of his chest he has a skull.

Changes at government-run B.C. Liquor Stores start today: 

‚Ä¢ New price tags will now show the cost of beer, wine, and spirits before taxes. (Old tags included the price.)
‚Ä¢ Stores will be open later, and on Sundays and holidays (to match private liquor stores).
‚Ä¢ They will now be allowed to install fridges to sell cold beer and wine. (Finally!)
‚Ä¢ Some grocery stores are allowed to sell B.C. wine now, but it's unclear when they will actually do it.

Cheers!

Coquitlam RCMP are looking for a man who reportedly tried to lure a girl into his car with an iPod or an iPad.

A 12-year-old girl told police it happened Tuesday. She refused his offer and kept walking. He followed her in his red car but got caught at a red light. The girl stuck to her route and lost sight of the car, said police.

The man is described a 35-40-year-old white male with balding brownish-blonde hair. He was driving a dirty, white, four-door sedan with a grey interior.

Anyone with information on the incident is asked to call Coquitlam RCMP at 604-945-1550 and quote file number 2015-9053.

Donald Lyle Salahub, 44, is wanted on a Canada-wide warrant for  violating his parole, and he's also a "person of interest" in the death of an Abbotsford man, said police.

Michael Amy, 34, was found dead in a vehicle in Surrey on Feb. 27.

Investigators want to speak to Salahub, who is originally from Manitoba, in relation to the killing. He violated his parole when he disappeared from a half-way house in last month.

Salahub has connections across Western Canada and has previously had dealings with police in the interior of British Columbia, said police.

Salahub is 5'11", over 200 pounds, and has brown hair and brown eyes.

Anyone who may have information about his whereabouts can call the IHIT tipline at 1-877-551-IHIT (4448) or email ihittipline@rcmp-grc.gc.ca.

Police are looking for Daniel Paul, a suspect in a Vancouver woman's killing. 

The 36-year-old woman was found in the basement suite of a home on East 22nd Avenue near Main Street on March 3. Police believe she was murdered. 

Paul, 42, is 5'8" tall and has a medium build. He has brown eyes and short black hair. On his left arm, he has tattoos of an eagle, a rat, a knife, a skull and a buffalo. On his right arm, he has tattoos of a skull with a rose and a heart.

(Photo: Vancouver Police Department)

That chemical fire is now out at Port Metro Vancouver. This photo by Vancouver Fire and Rescue Services shows what crews were up against.

Fred Latremouille, the man behind a familiar voice on Vancouver airwaves, has died at age 69. He passed away Thursday after a brief illness at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., said a brief statement from his wife, Cathy.

Latremouille was best known for his radio show on CFUN and KISS-FM in Vancouver, but he was also an actor, weatherman, and host. He was a member of the Canadian Broadcasters Hall of Fame and has a star on the B.C. Walk of Fame.

He met his wife on air and they spent 35 years together. Latremouille also leaves behind his mother, stepfather, sisters, brothers, many nieces, nephews, and friends. 

(Photo: Radiowest.ca)

UPDATE: Acting on a public tip, police arrested Mark Spelrem on Feb. 24 at around 8 p.m. in the 300 block of Powell Street.

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver police are looking for a suspect, and warning sex workers to be extra vigilant after two women were violently assaulted last week. 

A man contacted the two victims online on Feb. 19 and asked them to go to a West End apartment. Once inside, the women (both aged 30) were allegedly confined and sexually assaulted. They eventually managed to escape and call police. 

Mark Stacy Spelrem, 45, is wanted in the case. He's described as white, 5'11" tall, with a slim build. He has short dyed blond-orange hair that's spiked at the front and balding in the back, said police.

UPDATE: Police have located Jason Bresnahan, said a news release on Monday (Feb. 23).

ORIGINAL POST: Vancouver Police are looking for Jason Bresnahan, 39, a high-risk sex offender who is wanted for failing to return to his Vancouver halfway house last night. 

Bresnahan is a federal offender on statutory release after serving a five-year sentence for several crimes including the sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl, said police. He has previous convictions related to child pornography, assaults, threatening and property crime, and has been assessed as a high risk to re-offend sexually and violently

He's described as white, 5'11" tall, 270 lbs. with brown shaved hair and was last wearing a bright blue T-shirt. He has a tattoo of "Rae-Lene" on his right forearm, "Alison" on his left wrist and the number 13 on his right hand.

Anyone who sees Jason Bresnahan should not approach him and should call police.

High-risk sex offender, Stanley Lee Porter, is wanted after failing to return to his halfway house Friday night, said Vancouver police. 

Porter, 44, is a two-time federal offender who is currently serving a long term supervision order following a conviction for sexual assault. He has an extensive criminal history dating back more than two decades including convictions for sexual assault and sexual interference.

Porter has no direct ties to Vancouver and may travel outside of the Lower Mainland. He is described as aboriginal, 5'3" tall, 180 pounds and was last seen wearing a dark blue hooded jacket and blue jeans.

Abbotsford police have issued a public warning about Kenneth Courtney Breckenridge, 49. They fear he will re-offend, particularly in the context of an intimate relationship.

His criminal history includes assault, assault with a weapon, sexual assault causing bodily harm, forcible confinement and failing to comply with court orders. His victims have often been domestic/common-law partners, said police. 

Breckenridge is 6'1" tall and weighs 175 pounds and has brown hair and blue eyes. He lives in Abbotsford. 

Anyone seeing him violate court-ordered conditions (cannot leave B.C. without official permission, cannot possess weapons, must notify probation officer of intimate relationships) is asked to call police.

UPDATE: Police arrested Andrew Baldwin in East Vancouver on Thursday evening. 

ORIGINAL POST: U.S. citizen Andrew Charles Baldwin is wanted for the alleged attempted murder of a 28-year-old woman in East Vancouver.

Shortly after 10 p.m. Wednesday police responded to a report that a woman had been stabbed in an East Van apartment. They found an injured woman and took her to the hospital, where she's currently in stable condition.

Baldwin is wanted for attempted murder and aggravated assault. He is six-feet-tall with a stocky build.

Anyone who knows the whereabouts of Andrew Baldwin is asked to call 9-1-1 or Crime Stoppers at 1 (800) 222-8477.

(Photo: Vancouver police)

The law school at The University of British Columbia (UBC) is being renamed after Peter A. Allard who donated $30 million to the faculty on Thursday.

The lawyer, businessman, and philanthropist is an UBC alumnus, and previously gave almost $12 million to the school for Allard Hall, the Allard Prize for International Integrity and the law school's History Project online archive.

A local dealership was so moved by a single mom's plight that they gave her a free vehicle!

Jane Scott's car was stolen from outside her East Vancouver apartment over the Christmas holidays and found later in Surrey, completely destroyed. The single mother of two didn't have comprehensive auto insurance and couldn't afford to pay for a new one.

After reading her story in The Vancouver Sun, OpenRoad Auto Group and OpenRoad Hyundai - Richmond decided to donate a 2006 Hyundai Tucson and three years of free oil changes to her. She got the keys on Tuesday.

(Photo courtesy OpenRoad)

status_message:
RCMP dog handler Sgt. Derek King is being praised for saving a two-year-old girl from a house fire in Surrey on Thursday. 

The officer, who was off-duty at the time, was out for a walk when he saw smoke and flames coming from a home, said a news release. When he knocked on the door, a woman answered and said her granddaughter was trapped inside.

Without any protective gear, King rushed into the house, and through thick smoke, felt his way to the girl. He then scooped her up and brought her safely outside.

The cause of the fire has not been determined but police do not believe it's suspicious.

(Photo courtesy Surrey Fire Service)

Lots of weather related issues in B.C. Some very big rocks (pictured) have closed Highway 22A south of Trail. 

A rockslide has shut down Highway 12 north of Lytton, and avalanche control on Highway 1 is causing delays at Rogers Pass.

You've heard of bait cars? Now RCMP are using bait sleds across B.C. to try and nab snowmobile thieves.

Around 150 tires were slashed in North Vancouver overnight. Many of the vandalized cars were parked between Capilano University and the Park and Tilford neighbourhood. RCMP are asking people in that area to double check their tires this morning and to avoid getting behind the wheel if their tires are flat.

If you saw anything suspicious last night, call RCMP who are searching for suspects.

Happy December from our office in Yaletown!

UPDATE, 11:34 a.m.: Pennell has been arrested without incident, say police.

Police are looking for find Gerry Ronald Pennell, 54, a suspect in a downtown Vancouver shooting.

Just before 5 p.m. last night, police responded to a report of shots being fired in the west lane of Hornby and Helmcken, according to a news release. When they arrived, they found a scooter with multiple bullet holes in it. The scooter's driver, a 43-year-old woman, was not hurt and ran to St. Paul's hospital. Police believe she was targeted because of an ongoing dispute.

Pennell is 5'11" and 190 lbs. He was wearing a dark-coloured hoodie and cargo pants and is considered armed and dangerous. Anyone who sees him is asked to call 9-1-1.

(Photo: Vancouver police)

UPDATE - Nov. 28, 2014: Jason Beaudry has changed plans and is going to live in #Vancouver, instead of Cranbrook as was announced this week, said the Ministry of Justice corrections branch.

ORIGINAL POST: B.C. justice officials have issued a public warning about high-risk, violent sex offender Jason Beaudry, 37. He's being released in #Kamloops and plans to live in #Cranbrook.

He has at least 70 convictions, including violent and sexual offences and weapons charges, involving men, women, strangers and acquaintances, said BC Corrections.

Beaudry, who is 5'11" tall and 180 pounds, is subject to close monitoring and 13 court-ordered conditions including following a curfew, and avoiding places with alcohol or drugs.

"Being an entrepreneur is a lot like a real life game of Mike Tyson's punch out. Competition, rules, [and] situations will hit you with a solid upper cut and knock you down hard. You gotta keep your eye on your vision, and strategically land your jabs, find a weakness or gap, and make your move. Eventually you'll take Iron Mike down, but don't expect it in one quick blow. Chin up and keep fighting!" ‚Äî Donnie Ungaro, CEO of Culinary Ink in #Kelowna

"Support your surrounding community and they will support you back! I've learned that even though finding local suppliers may take a little bit longer and cost a little bit more, it's more than worth it. Get involved in community events and find ways to give back; it all comes full circle!" ‚Äî Alexandrea Rose, co-founder of The Juicery Co.

Langley RCMP released this sketch of a suspect who attacked someone with a hammer.

On Oct. 18 around 3 a.m., two attackers armed with a gun were robbing a woman in the 20200 block of 56 Avenue in Langley. A man tried to intervene and instead was hit with a hammer repeatedly and beaten.

The attackers fled in a newer silver car, possibly a Hyundai or Toyotal four-door, said Langley RCMP. 

The victim was treated in hopsital for a serious skull fracture.

One suspect is possibly Filipino, 6'1" tall, mid to late 20s, about 200 pounds with an athletic build. He was bal with a tattoo on his neck written in script. The second suspect is white, 5'10" tall, mid to late 20s, skinny and "scrubby looking," said police.

status_message:
Update: Vancouver police have caught Allard. He attempted to flee on foot, but was eventually taken into custody, said police on Sunday morning. 

Original post: High-risk sex offender Kelsey Alexander Allard, 31, is wanted for not returning to his halfway house last night as required. 

He served just short of five years for sexual assault, threatening, overcome resistance by choking and forcible confinement. 

Assessed as a high risk to re-offend sexually and violently, he is described as white, 5'10" tall, 165 lbs., with short brown hair, blue eyes and glasses. He has tattoos on both forearms and was last seen wearing a black hoody with a red design across the front, blue jeans and black and white runners.

Allard has ties to both the Lower Mainland and Prince George. If you see him, do not approach him and call 911 immediately, say police. 

(Photo: Vancouver Police Dept.)

UPDATE: Police arrested a suspect on Saturday and are recommending theft charges. 

Recognize this guy? He's wanted for stealing two poppy donation boxes from a drugstore and a gas station in North Vancouver on Tuesday night. 

If you have a tip, call the North Vancouver RCMP at 604-985-1311 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS.

status_message:
UPDATE - Sept. 27, 2014: The Vancouver Police Department says Julian Halfe has been located and is back in custody.

ORIGINAL POST: A Canada-wide arrest warrant has been issued for Julian Halfe, who broke his parole when he left his halfway house on Thursday. 

He is on statutory release serving a federal sentence for robbery and assault and is considered a high risk to re-offend violently.

He is 5'6" tall and 143 lbs., and has several visible tattoos including full sleeves on both arms. He was last seen wearing a baseball hat with a red "C" and red brim, a black hooded jacket with thin white stripe on the arms, dark baggy blue jeans, black shoes, and a black backpack.

status_message:
UPDATE - Sept. 26: A private collector has voluntarily surrendered the mask to RCMP, and a suspect has been arrested.

ORIGINAL POST: 
A First Nations mask was stolen from a shed in Alert Bay last week. (It looks like this one from the Museum of Anthropology at UBC.) 

The mask depicts Huxhukw, one of three bird masks used by the peoples of the Kwakwaka'wakw in ceremonies. It has special cultural and historical significance because their use was banned in Canada from the late 1800s until 1951.

RCMP said it's likely that someone will try to sell it to a gallery or private collector. Anyone in possession of this item, knowing it was obtained through a break, enter and theft, may themselves be committing a crime, said police.
"I'm here for him to learn with his peers ‚Äî social skills, development skills, solving problems skills," said one mother. "I want him to be where he is right now." #bced #bcpoli

A public warning has been issued for high-risk sex offender Richard Ian Ellis, 66, who will be living in Vancouver after completing his prison sentence. He was convicted in 2007 for sexually assaulting a seven-year-old girl and for child pornography charges.

"Police believe that he poses a risk of significant harm to the safety of young girls," said a news release.

Ellis is white, 5'10" tall and 200 lbs., with brown hair and hazel eyes. He must follow the following release conditions to:
 ‚Ä¢ not be in possession of a computer for accessing the internet
 ‚Ä¢ not be found in the company of children under 18 years
 ‚Ä¢ not have contact with the victim
 ‚Ä¢ not consume alcohol or drugs
 ‚Ä¢ report all relationships.

Anyone who sees Ellis violating any condition is asked to call 911.

#Nanaimo RCMP are looking for a man who tried to grab a woman by the arm through her driver's side window.

The scary incident began on Thursday evening when the 44-year-old woman was driving an older model Ford Escort on Brechin Road, said police. The driver of a late '90s Ford F150 truck pulled up and yelled something but she ignored him. He continued to follow her, honk his horn and flash his lights.

Thinking there was something wrong with her vehicle, she slowed down. The man then cut his truck in front of her forcing her to pull over and stop.

He walked to her door and said "I want to take you for coffee." As she tried to power up her window, he reached in and grabbed her. She broke his grip by speeding off. "She was left with bruising on her arm and was traumatized by her ordeal," said RCMP.

 The suspect is described as:
¬∑         white , 40's, good looking  with an athletic build
¬∑         salt and pepper hair in a military style cut
¬∑         pale, clean shaven,light coloured eyes
¬∑         high pitched voice, like that of a teenager
¬∑         cleft shin and white mark on the bridge of nose, similar to a scar
¬∑         wearing a white T-shirt with a dragon symbol
¬∑         metal banded watch on his left wrist

Anyone with information or might have witnessed this is asked to call Nanaimo RCMP.

Surrey RCMP are trying to identify a man who is believed to have assaulted a 16-year-old girl.

On July 27 the girl was walking on a pathway behind Clayton Heights Secondary school when the man came up behind her and put his arm around her neck. She screamed and he ran away.

The suspect is described as a white male in his mid-30s, six feet tall, with a medium build and dark hair. At the time of the assault he was wearing a rusty/tan coloured tank top and black shorts.
 
Anyone with any information is asked to call the Surrey RCMP at 604-599-0502.

Vancouver police have issued a public warning about Patrick Henry, a violent offender considered a high risk to re-offend violently against women. 

Henry, 36, frequents Vancouver's Downtown Eastside and is believed to be using online dating sites to meet women, said police.

He's described as aboriginal, 5'6" tall, and 181 pounds. He's on probation for domestic assault and must not:
- Possess knives except for the purpose of preparing or eating food
- Consume alcohol or non-prescription drugs
- Be found in any place licensed to serve alcohol
 
Anyone who sees Henry violating of any of his conditions is asked to call 911.

(Photo: Vancouver Police Department)

Victoria police dog Conan successfully tracked a suspect wanted in a violent assault for more than a kilometre and over an hour early Thursday. He led officers from a home through a hole cut in a chain-link fence, through the bush, and to some abandoned military buildings. A 22-year-old Esquimalt man surrendered peacefully and is facing charges.

We think Conan deserves a treat or two.

(Photo: Victoria Police Department)

Updated story here: http://huff.to/1o9NCKw

Coquitlam RCMP are looking for Pancho Desperatus-Amator-DeTanza, who went missing from Cottonwood Lodge, a mental health facility on the old Riverview Hospital grounds. He was last seen by staff on Tuesday morning wearing a dark grey plaid shirt and blue jeans. He's 6'2" and 180 pounds. 

"Desperatus-Amator-DeTanza suffers from a mental disorder and should not be approached," said police.

In 2004, Desperatus-Amator-DeTanza got into an argument with an official at the Canadian consulate in Paraguay and shot him in the shoulder, according to a local newspaper.

Surrey RCMP are trying to find a man who was trespassing and viciously stabbed a dog in its own yard. 

The man was apparently taking a shortcut through private property in the 12700 block of 58th Avenue on April 28 around 7:30 p.m. When the owner's barking Belgium Shepherd confronted him, the man attacked the dog with a knife, said police.

Spirit the dog suffered multiple stab wounds to his face and head that required extensive surgery.

Surrey RCMP released an image of the suspect today and hope you can help find him.

Springer, the B.C. orphan killer whale who was successfully rehabilitated and reunited with her pod, has a baby of her own now ‚Äî and you can help name it.

The calf has survived its first year ‚Äî the most challenging period in every whale's life ‚Äî and now needs a name, says the Vancouver Aquarium Marine Mammal Rescue Centre.

You can email your gender-neutral suggestion to adoption@vanaqua.org, along with a sentence or two about the significance of the suggestion. (It's not known yet if the calf is male or female.)

Nominations will be open until July 16, and voting will begin July 18. The winning name will be announced later this month.

(Photo: Christy MacMillan)

Langley RCMP is seeking information to help identify a man who assaulted a woman in May.

The woman was walking along Industrial Avenue around 2 a.m. when a brown two door vehicle pulled up next to her. There were two men inside and one of them asked her if she wanted a ride. When she said no and kept walking, the man got out of the car and hit her on the back of the head.

She was able to get back on her feet and run to a gas station for safety.
 
The suspect is described as Caucasian, approximately 5'10", 180 lbs., skinny, wearing a light coloured plaid shirt.

Anyone with information is asked to call Langley RCMP at 604-532-3200.

Vancouver police have issued a public warning for sex offender, Donald Joseph Scott. He is free after a 13.5-year sentence for the sexual assault and attempted murder of a teenage boy. Scott also has a long criminal history of other violent crimes, said police. 
 
Scott is a high risk for violent and sexual re-offending, especially to the safety of children and young people, said police.
 
Scott is 34 years old, 5'8" tall, 186 lbs., with brown hair, a beard and blue eyes.
 
He must follow several conditions including staying away from liquor stores, bars, and places where people under 16 might be present.

Today in 1917, #Vancouver Police Chief Constable Malcolm MacLennan was killed in the line of duty. 

On March 20, 1917, a tenant named Robert Tait who lived in an apartment above a grocery store on East Georgia Street was threatening his landlord. When police arrived, Tait fired a rifle through the door, injuring the landlord and an officer who both lost an eye each.

While police waited for backup, Tait fired out of his window, killing an eight-year-old boy who was going to the store below to buy candy.

Chief MacLennan left his own 10-year-old son's birthday party to attend and supervise the standoff. When negotiations failed, he lead a team into the apartment. 

Tait, armed with two rifles, two revolvers and a shotgun, shot and killed MacLennan as he came through the door. The ensuing gun battle ended when Tait killed himself before he could be arrested.

MacLennan also left a legacy of authorizing the formation of the Vancouver Police Pipe Band, which continues today.

(Photo: Vancouver Police Department)

"The facts of the case are clear: the rhetoric of government of seeking labour peace and stability and of providing parents and students with flexibility and choice is duplicitous. The intention was to rob the system of the funding it needs and to use teachers as scapegoats in the quest to get re-elected.

Far from "the highest funding ever," the B.C. Liberals now are claiming restoration of our bargaining language will mean a re-investment in public education of significant funding. They now have to admit publicly that their rhetoric of highest funding ever was a manipulation and deception."

A Coquitlam man who's been charged with sex offences may have other unknown victims that he met on social media, warned Surrey RCMP.

Joel Scarff, 38, allegedly uses social media to meet and date women -- and then uses them to meet his younger victims, said police in a Friday news release. 

Scarff is charged with four counts of sexual interference and two counts of invitation to sexual touching on multiple persons under the age of 16. He's been released under several conditions.

Surrey RCMP are concerned there may be more victims who have not come forward. Anyone with more info can contact the Child Abuse and Sexual Offence Unit at 604-599-0502 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS if you wish to remain anonymous.

(Photo: RCMP)

The E! Entertainment network is apologizing to B.C.-born actor Michael J. Fox for an online graphic during its Golden Globes coverage that listed his Parkinson's Disease as a "fun fact." 

"We understand the serious nature of the disease and sincerely apologize," said the network's statement.

The graphic was shown during E!'s live stream of red carpet coverage Sunday, although not on TV.

A suspect wanted in the sexual assault of a Japanese woman may be targetting foreign exchange students, said Transit Police in Metro Vancouver.

The force released surveillance video of the man, who is wanted in the incident at the Gateway SkyTrain station in Surrey.

The student, 29, was buying transit fare in the station when the man in his late 50s approached her to help. He then forced himself on her, repeatedly kissing and hugging her, according to Transit Police on Sunday.

The woman was able to finally push him away. She went to the train platform and got in a SkyTrain, while the suspect left the station on foot shortly after, said Transit Police.

The incident happened in September but the victim, who spoke little English, was traumatized and did not report the incident to police at the time. She later told her homestay host, who encouraged her to go to police.

Transit Police spokeswoman Anne Drennan told CBC News it's likely the suspect has done this before and will continue doing it.

He is described as a white male with short blonde hair, 5'5" tall, 130 pounds, with hazel eyes.

UPDATE: Ching Chi Lam has been located.

The Vancouver police are seeking the public's help to find Ching Chi Lam, a missing woman with dementia who walked away from her home on Harrison Drive, near Victoria Drive, at around 2 p.m. on Wednesday afternoon.

Ms. Lam is Asian, 81 years old, 5'2" tall, 120 pounds, has short black hair and wears glasses. She speaks limited English and awlks with a walker.

She uses transit and often travels by bus or train to Richmond's Aberdeen Centre, and also takes the SeaBus to Lonsdale Quay in North Vancouver.

(Photo courtesy of VPD)

MISSING PERSON ALERT: 19-year-old Rene Durelle of Kelowna

His mother has not heard from him since Sept. 28. He has no fixed address, and suffers from Depression and other psychological issues. He has gone missing in the past, but has not been out of contact for this length of time.

He is described as Caucasian, 180 cm (5'11"), 59 kg (130 lbs), thin build, pale complexion and has brown hair and blue eyes. Anyone with information should call Kelowna RCMP at 250-762-3300 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-8477.

The Langley RCMP are seeking 14-year-old Allie Rickards, who left her grandmother's home in the 22600-block of Old Yale Road at 7 a.m. on Wednesday and has not returned.

Rickards was on her way to catch a bus to school in North Delta. Her parents have confirmed that she did not attend any classes that day, nor a scheduled dance club meeting.

Rickards was staying with her grandmother to have some time away from her parents and was expected back after school. She had left home before but family have always been able to confirm where she was. That was not the case this time.

She's described as a white female, 5'5" tall, 150 pounds, with brown hair and brown eyes.

- mid-length brownish-red hair

The Northern Gateway pipeline's risks are far worse than Enbridge has so far admitted, says an SFU study.

Among its analysis

- the likelihood of a tanker spill ranges from one every 23 years to one every 196 years ‚Äî higher than the one every 250 years estimated by Enbridge 
- there are likely to be 15 to 16 pipeline spills a year on land, compared to Enbridge's estimate of one every two years
- a significant oil spill at the tanker terminal that would be built in Kitimat, B.C., as part of the project is possible once every 15 to 41 years, compared to the company estimate of once every 62 years

The owners of Festival Cinemas, the company that once operated the Ridge Theatre, Fifth Avenue Cinemas and the Park Theatre, offered this statement today:

"We want to thank all of you for supporting us for so many years. We have tried to show the best movies available and hire staff that treated our film goers with respect by going the extra distance to make your visit to our theatres as enjoyable as possible.

We are very proud to have been involved with and support many local charities, non-profit societies and local organizations. 

Cineplex Entertainment will be operating Fifth Avenue Cinemas and the Park Theatre starting March 1. They will be showing the same kind of films and will be keeping all of our staff. 

After 35 years in the film industry and turning 65 this year, we have decided to retire.

Yours,

Tom Lightburn and Leonard Schein"

Vancouver Island photographer Paul Nicklen won first prize (nature stories) by World Press Photo with this shot of Emperor Penguins in the Ross Sea, Antarctica.

New science shows that Emperor Penguins are capable of tripling their swimming speed by releasing millions of bubbles from their feathers. These bubbles reduce the friction between their feathers and the icy seawater, allowing them to accelerate in the water. 

(Photo credit: AP Photo/Paul Nicklen, National Geographic magazine)

Allan Schoenborn, who killed his three children in Merritt, asked to move from a B.C. psychiatric hospital to one in Manitoba to be closer to his family. "I miss my mom," he said.
